comments.body: Is there a reason you do this? As the code below works fine for a class as well, eg pandas.DataFrame (while now the script will say the keywords and signature did not match, while in fact they do)

I didn't research much, but if I introspect parameters from a non-function I get this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 353, in <module>
    sys.exit(main(args.function))
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 337, in main
    return validate_all()
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 259, in validate_all
    int(doc.correct_parameters),
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 159, in correct_parameters
    return not bool(self.parameter_mismatches)
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 138, in parameter_mismatches
    signature_params = self.signature_parameters
  File "./validate_docstrings.py", line 130, in signature_parameters
    params = tuple(inspect.signature(self.method_obj).parameters.keys())
  File "/home/mgarcia/.anaconda3/envs/pandas_dev/lib/python3.6/inspect.py", line 3036, in signature
    return Signature.from_callable(obj, follow_wrapped=follow_wrapped)
  File "/home/mgarcia/.anaconda3/envs/pandas_dev/lib/python3.6/inspect.py", line 2786, in from_callable
    follow_wrapper_chains=follow_wrapped)
  File "/home/mgarcia/.anaconda3/envs/pandas_dev/lib/python3.6/inspect.py", line 2341, in _signature_from_callable
    'no signature found for builtin type {!r}'.format(obj))
ValueError: no signature found for builtin type <class 'pandas.core.indexing._AtIndexer'>
```
Is it difficult to find the accessors that have been registered, instead of hardcoding them here? So we don't need to remember to change this when a new accessor is created.

Yeah, I was looking into the class (eg that I could check they inherit from a base Accessor class, but that's not consistent between them). 
So not really sure there is a better way, but totally agree it is not ideal.
Actually, there is a `_accessors` attribute. But not fully sure to what extent we can rely on that.
The problem is then that I need to get the class (eg Series in case of pandas.Series.dt), which is also difficult to introspect. So maybe the easiest is to leave it as is.
Sure, it's quite useful as it is, we can improve it in the future if we find a way.

FYI: https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/19963

I think `isinstance(object.__getattribute__(self, method_obj.__name__), CachedAccessor)` might have done it, But having an official registry is better :)

There are actually some cases where I see people deliberately leaving a blank line at the end of the docstring (see eg examples in http://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_numpy.html. Also numpydoc does it in the example: http://numpydoc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/format.html, although not sure if it is on purpose). 

So not sure we should be that strict here.
It's your call, but personally I think that if there is no specific reason to leave one line sometimes, and to not leave it other times, I'd define a standard way to do it.

Somehow I have a personal preference to leave a blank line at the end .. :-) 
But since the way you check it now is most occurring way in pandas, let's pick that.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +391,395 @@                    'the last text in the docstring (do not close the '
                    'quotes in the same line as the text, or leave a '
                    'blank line between the last text and the quotes)')
    if doc.double_blank_lines:
        errs.append('Use only one blank line to separate sections or '

comments.body: tuple -> list ?
Did the opposite, but yes, fixed. :)

This does not seem to work for me. Eg checking `pandas.Series.dt` with the script complains about parameter 'data' not being documented.

(but anyhow, it is better as on master, there it raises an attribute error somewhere in the script)
Good to know. Iâ€™d be happy to open that up as a follow up issue here - worth adding dedicated tests for accessors
'\t' in line is good enough, yes? we don't all *any* tabs
If you see the comments above @TomAugspurger requested "Starts with tab" as there might be tabs to format a table or the like I think
ok, not sure this is actually strict enough. as I said we don't allow *any* tabs
I'm happy to change it back to allow no tabs at all. Let me know what you think @TomAugspurger

@jreback There are cases where a `\t` is included in the text as literal character (for the explanation).
So I think only checking the start of a line is good.
Unrelated to where `\t` is included, we could use `re.search(r'^ *\t', self.raw_doc, flags=re.MULTILINE)` and avoid the loop
ups, sorry, I see now that you want to report the lines with the tabs...
